item.question:
You are a regular user (not root) and want to examine the PCI bus configuration.
Which command can you use?
item.choice: None of the mentioned choices, it is only possible with <font face="monospace">root</font>-privileges.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to display the following three columns from /etc/passwd:
"username (first column), user id (third column) and login directory" (sixth column).
Which command will print these columns to screen?
item.hint: Remember what <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> uses as field separator. You may encounter commands as answers which are not covered in the LPI 101 objectives. Usually these are added to confuse you and are usually not correct.

item.question:
Suppose user pete has created a new application atop, and copied it to the directory /usr/local/bin.
On your system each user belongs to his/her own unique group.
For instance, user petra belongs to the group petra and pete belongs to the group pete.
You would like all the users who do not belong to the group and are not owner of the application to be able to run your application.
Which of the following command lines would allow the appropriate access?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You have setup quota-support for the home-directories.
Which command allows the sysadmin to set quotas for a specific user?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What will be the result of the above command?
item.choice: Changes directory to the user guru0's home directory
Changes to a directory named <font face="monospace">~guru0</font>
Changes to directory named <font face="monospace">guru0</font> in the current directory
item.correct_answer: Changes directory to the user guru0's home directory
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following can be used to switch your system to run level 1?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You downloaded a compressed file and want to display the contents (filenames) before extracting it.
The name of the downloaded file is stableos.tar.bz2.
Which single command (no options) can you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: In which directory would you look to see if a USB device was correctly detected by the kernel?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will show the number of free and used inodes for your system's mounted file systems?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command to skip checking the filesystems on reboot?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to remove a package from the system completely, including its configuration files.
Which dpkg command-option(s) should you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a file?
item.choice: nothing, sticky bit has only meaning when set on a directory
the file will be persistent in memory
the file can only be deleted by the owner or a user with root-privileges.
the file can never be deleted by a regular user
item.correct_answer: nothing, sticky bit has only meaning when set on a directory
item.hint: Remember we are talking Linux here.

item.question: Which of the following commands is implemented as a bash shell-builtin?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following syslog-priorities represents the highest level of importance?

You want to know the previous runlevel your system was running.
Which command can be used to find the previous runlevel?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to update a tar-archive you previously made.
Which option for the command tar best performs the given task?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You execute the above command.
What will be the result?
item.choice: Only filenames in the user's homedir will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All directorynames will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All filenames in the user's homedir and any errors reported by <font face="monospace">find</font> will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All filenames in the user's homedir will be printed in the terminal and any errors will be written to <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
item.correct_answer: All filenames in the user's homedir and any errors reported by <font face="monospace">find</font> will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You changed the file <font face="monospace">/etc/inittab</font>. What would be your next action to make the change effective?
item.choice: Use the command <font face="monospace">kill</font> to send the <font face="monospace">HUP</font> signal
item.correct_answer: Use the command <font face="monospace">kill</font> to send the <font face="monospace">HUP</font> signal
item.hint: Technically multiple answers are correct. However, LPI examinates good system administrator practices. That means minimizing downtime of the services you maintain.

item.question: Which command will show the first 10 lines of a file by default?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the maximum amount of devices, not including the host adapter, you can connect to a 16 bit SCSI card?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.exhibit:
# jobs -l
[1] Running firefox &
[2]- Stopped atop
[3]+ Stopped vi
item.question: Given the above exhibit, which command could you use to bring application 'vi' to the foreground?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is one of the purposes of the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard?
item.choice: It enables software to predict the location of files and directories.
It enables software to predict the ownership and permissions of files and directories.
It states which formatting (e.g. <font face="monospace">ext3</font>) should be used for which filesystem.
It states the default size of the filesystems.
item.correct_answer: It enables software to predict the location of files and directories.
item.hint: You may find none of the answers applicable. However, by eliminating answers that are obviously wrong you should able to find the correct answer.

item.question:
You are working on a Debian system and you made a mess of the samba configuration file.
Unfortunately you forgot to create a backup of the configuration file.
Which of the following would allow you to make a fresh start with the initial samba configuration from the debian samba package?
item.choice: It is not possible without reinstalling samba.

item.question:
Suppose you know that an application atop is installed on the current system.
You have examined the man and info pages for atop thoroughly, but you still have an appetite for more information about atop.
Which of the following directories is the BEST first place to look for further documentation files?
item.hint: The question could be rephrased as: What is the default location for documentation files?

item.question: Considering above exhibit, which command would add <font face="monospace">firewall</font> to the runlevel and start it before networking is started?
item.hint: The order is determined using Bash filename expansion, which is alphabetically.

item.question: Which command will display all the lines of the file <font face="monospace">foo</font> starting with a capital S?
item.hint: The question asks for a regular expression that matches a capital S at the beginning of each line.

item.question: Which command would you use to display how many inodes are available on the <font face="monospace">/home</font> filesystem?
item.hint: The answers only cover the commands <font face="monospace">du</font> and <font face="monospace">df</font>. So choosing the correct command gets you halfway. You will then only need to remember if the command requires an option or not to show the amount of available inodes.

item.question: According to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard (FHS), in which directory (full path name) should you look for system logfiles?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following items are specified in the file /etc/fstab.
Choose all correct answers.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to find the location on the filesystem of the command you previously executed.
Which command would you use?
item.hint: This question is about how Bash finds commands on the filesystem to execute not where a file with a certain name can be found on the filesystem.

item.question: Which command can be used to show all shell-variables?
item.hint: The Bash shell treats all variables equal but some are more equal than others. The most equal variables are exported to its children and the others are not. The question is about showing ALL variables, so not only the exported ones.

item.question:
You are looking for an executable file foo.
Select TWO commands that would search for foo within directories set in the shell variable $PATH.
item.hint: You are required to provide TWO answers. So select two, no more, no less. The question asks for an executable file, not just any file named <font face="monospace">foo</font>.

item.question: What option will allow a normal user to mount a filesystem and have only the user that mounted the filesystem unmount it?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is a disadvantage of using symbolic links over hard links?
item.choice: A symbolic link becomes disconnected from the underlying file if the file is moved.
A symbolic link can span different filesystems
The hard link uses the same inode as the original file, where a symbolic link has its own inode.
Removing a symbolic link does not remove the underlying file.
item.correct_answer: A symbolic link becomes disconnected from the underlying file if the file is moved.
item.hint: Although you personally might find more than one of the choices a disadvantage, the question is actually which of the following is the most disadvantage.

item.question: Which command line can be used to restart a running Linux system immediately?
item.hint: The question clearly states the system should restart IMMEDIATELY.

item.question:
Your current working directory contains the above files.
Which files are shown when you execute the command ls | grep 't[^o].$'?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">grep</font> uses regular expression syntax to specify the match filter. Brackets allow you to specify a set of characters that may occur at a single position. The caret inside brackets means you do not want the specified characters to match at that position. The dot (<font face="monospace">.</font>) means a single random character and the dollar sign (<font face="monospace">$</font>) means end of the line.

item.question: Which of the following commands can you use to create a new file called atcomputing?
item.hint: Although it is not stated explicitly multiple answers may be correct. If there are multiple correct answers you should select all to answer the question correctly.

item.question: Which of the following device names point to logical partitions?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can you use to create a link (<font face="monospace">newdir</font>) to an existing directory (<font face="monospace">existingdir</font>) in the same filesystem?
item.hint: Read the question carefully. It asks for creating a link to a DIRECTORY. Besides the order of the existing dir and the link you will need to know the limitations of creating a hard- and softlink to answer this question correctly.

item.question:
A job is running in the foreground.
Pressing [Ctrl]+[KEY] pauses this job and gives you control of the terminal.
What is [KEY]?
item.hint: The question is about a key combination pressing the control key and another key. The answer you must provide is the letter of the other key.

item.question:
You have added a sound card and suspect it might be conflicting with another device.
Therefore you check the file /proc/____________ to learn which IRQs are being used by other drivers loaded by the kernel.
Which of the following commands will print the usage of each mounted filesystem?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You need to install linux on a laptop with a 1.66 GHz processor, 2 GB of RAM and a 160 GB harddisk.
The user made clear he wants support for suspend and hibernation.
How much space on the disk would you allocate to be used as swap?
item.hint: Hibernation will write memory to the swap space. So the minimum amount of swap space required will be the amount of RAM in the system. However, this may be too limited as the system might have used some portion of the swap space to hold inactive memory pages when the physical RAM was or is full. To make sure there will be enough swap space left for hibernation a good rule of thumb is to allocate twice the amount of RAM as swap space.

item.question: What is the maximum amount of devices, not including the host adapter, you can connect to an 8 bit SCSI card?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You created a new filesystem on the first harddisk (sda) on its third partition which you will mount on /extra.
You now want to enable the quota system for users on this new filesystem.
Which of the following commands would you use to enable the quota-system and make it effective for users?
Choose all that apply.
item.choice: add the mount option <font face="monospace">usrquota</font> to the <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font> options column for
add the filesystem with mountpoint <font face="monospace">/extra</font> to <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>
item.correct_answer: add the mount option <font face="monospace">usrquota</font> to the <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font> options column for
add the filesystem with mountpoint <font face="monospace">/extra</font> to <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When you run the command mycommand you want to redirect the output to a file.
Which command will accomplish this and will make sure no other output is sent to the console?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commandlines allows you to see the difference between the content of
the tar archive and the current content of the directory /home?
item.hint: Even if you never used <font face="monospace">tar</font> in this way you may be able to answer this question correctly by eliminating the wrong answers.

item.question:
You have a text file (hitchhiker.txt) in which you want to replace every 'arthur' by 'Arthur'.
You decide to use sed to make this happen.
What is the correct commandline?
item.hint: The question states you want to replace EVERY arthur with Arthur. Hence, you should do a global replacement. Also note that the file <font face="monospace">hitchhiker.txt</font> should be updated. The question does not mention anything about creating a new file.

item.exhibit:
Bill Howes
Steve Lops
June Lops
Joan Read
Steve Read
item.question:
Consider the above output from a file called employees.
Which command will NOT sort this file appropriately on family names?
item.choice:
cut -f 2 -d " " employees | paste employees - |
sort -k 3 | cut -f 1
item.hint: If you did not read the question clearly you may think multiple answers are correct. But beware the questions asks for the command that will NOT, I repeat NOT, sort the file appropriately on family names.

item.question:
Which of the following command lines can (possibly) be used to format a partition?
Assume that logical partitioning is used on each hard-disk.
item.hint: The question does not state anything about the filesystem type. Although you see <font face="monospace">ext2</font> and <font face="monospace">msdos</font> as possible filesystem types you can disregard this information and both may be correct.

item.question: What is the devicefile of the first primary partition on the second SCSI-harddisk?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which run level represents a power down?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the result of the above command?
item.choice: You will get the shell secondary prompt
The text echo ATcomputing will be printed
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which runlevels should you NOT select as default runlevel in /etc/inittab?
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: The question is not about which runlevels are actually used on a Linux system. The question asks which runlevels you should NOT select in order to get a workable running system.

item.question:
When you create a new directory, you see the permissions are set to rwx--x---.
Which umask value would cause this to happen?
item.hint: When creating a directory the command <font face="monospace">mkdir</font> asks for a certain set of permissions and <font face="monospace">umask</font> is used to determine what the directory will eventually get. In general, the permissions asked when creating a directory are different from when creating a new file.

item.question:
You just got a new disk and want to make it accessible for users.
Which command(s) do you require to perform this task?
Select all that apply.
item.hint: The question is about setting up a fresh new harddisk for general usage on a Linux system. You should select all commands you will need to accomplish the task.

item.question: Which command will display a list with all installed RPMs?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands will create a symbolic link?
item.hint: The question is about creating SYMBOLIC links, not HARD links.

item.question: Which file is the main configuration file for the init process?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following is true about the <font face="monospace">lost+found</font> directory?
item.choice: It is not mentioned in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.
Every directory has a <font face="monospace">lost+found</font> subdirectory.
It contains unlinked files found by <font face="monospace">fsck</font>.
item.correct_answer: It is not mentioned in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.
It contains unlinked files found by <font face="monospace">fsck</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.
